drastically impact what you choose because certain platforms will require
more developers certain platforms like cross-platform or cross-platform frameworks or

time to market app performance this is becoming less of a
problem less of a consideration nowadays but it is still something to keep in mind i i keep it on this list even though
most phones nowadays are powerful enough to where performance really isn't a
problem no matter which framework you go with and also the frameworks have matured a

improve their performance as well but if you're using or if you're creating an
app that needs to be very performant maybe it's um some sort of 3d game that's rendering
a lot of graphics then yeah performance is definitely something to keep in mind
that being said most apps nowadays are just data entry apps where we're
entering in text or we're scrolling through lists and so for i'd say 95 98
of mobile apps performance is going to be fine across the board but if you're
rendering those 3d graphics or doing something crazy like ar vr definitely keep performance in mind

lot of developers end up shooting themselves in the foot because they choose a framework
that doesn't have a feature that they need so speaking of doing things in ar or
vr so augmented reality virtual reality well if you make a progressive web app
it can't do any of that or it can't do any of that natively using the native apis for ios and android and
so if maybe you want to include something like geofencing or augmented reality

do know that it is a risk going with a third party framework

they will draw a button on the screen and it is the native button and it's made to

design that they promote in their human interface design guidelines
and so when i say put a button in the center of the screen i get this very simple button it's actually just blue text so it
almost looks like a hyperlink whereas when i do the same on android and say put a android widget button
on the side of the screen well i get this nice material designed with buttons with square corners and shadows
android likes to use material design which shows off a lot of elevation so we get a lot of shadows and kind of ripple animations which are

we'll talk about in this presentation the development the the development

you essentially have to create the same app twice well you do you have to you have to create the same app twice

that app using either swift or objective-c and then when you want to publish that

we can't reuse the same code and also because ios and android promote
different architectures for architecting your apps you end up with
an app that has a similar look and feel on both ios and android but the code that powers it is

speaking of maintenance costs which will which are i also have flagged as high which again means higher than the other
alternatives is when you find bugs you have to fix them on
both platforms when you want to add a new feature well you have to add it in both

ios and android because they're two completely different code bases so
what you're looking at is either having two dedicated teams one to write your
swift code for ios one to write your java or kotlin code for android
or you have one team that pivots between the two so one common approach is to create the ios
app first we'll create one of the apps first so let's say you create the ios app first
and then once it's done you essentially port that code into java or kotlin for
android so i've seen teams do this where they put their senior engineers on the ios team build
that out get the ios app in the app store first because maybe they know their target market is

and and that's one approach to doing it but you still will have to build

but the benefit here is your performance is going to be very high so compared to all of the

okay so moving on into the third-party tools the next subject we'll talk about is
progressive web apps so first we should probably answer the
question what is a progressive web app well it says web app in the in the name and
so that kind of implies that it's a website and that's exactly what it is it's a website but
the difference between a web app and a progressive web app is progressive web apps or pwas
if you'll hear me say that abbreviation a lot uh pwas are different from normal web apps
because when you visit a website in your browser so let's imagine we're on our laptop we've got
chrome opened up and we navigate to a website in the browser if it's just a normal web web app
that website is built and running on the server side so we're just seeing the
essentially just the ui but all that business logic the guts and of the um if you're doing anything with
databases or anything like that that's all running server side progressive web apps
flip that so when you visit a website that's a progressive web app the website actually downloads to your
client so to your browser and everything runs client-side and so they you get
that ability to have everything run more smoothly
i've also seen some amazing 3d games built using progressive web apps because then they can take advantage of the
horsepower on your computer there's no latency from communicating with the server and so pwas
all run on the client side now how does how does this come into mobile
well i've i've chosen to focus on pwas
and not not web apps because web apps were always an option for
creating a mobile app you could always essentially build a website and jam it into a mobile app and deploy
that to the app store and yeah that worked but it doesn't look great
the users can tell when it's not native like when you load an app and it doesn't have a good response time or it doesn't
use like it doesn't have buttons where you would expect the buttons to be it just feels weird
that's usually because it's a web app but with progressive web apps we're not relying
on the server anymore and we're running everything on the client side so we get a huge improvement bump there
and so if you are interested in using web technologies for a mobile app
don't even look at normal we'll say normal web apps jump straight to progressive web apps

7. and because you have a bespoke ui you now have to recreate that entire ui

people developers love using flutter flutter was it is created by
google and the big difference with flutter compared
to xamarin and react native is your ui is actually totally bespoke
so in the same way with progressive web apps that we had to create our own ui the way
we're doing the same on flutter the way flutter works is instead of instead of
using those native ios uis or ui apis like the ui button
they actually just draw your ui on the screen they use a technology called skia
and if you can picture a blank canvas just like an artist would have with and the same way the artist paints onto
the canvas that's how flutter works so it essentially
mimics the look and feel of a native app but the ui is totally drawn on and
they've gone down this route because they've actually found that you can get better performance by
just drawing the ui onto a blank canvas instead of using the native ios and android controls
now that better performance does have a an asterisk on it a caveat and that
it is better performance for some apps but not better performance for others just kind of depends on what
you're working on how busy and complex your ui is but do be aware that flutter is a
bespoke ui and they do also have libraries that
will help you mimic the ios and android look and feel so they have
uh like for example material design guidelines so that you can drop those in and then that
button will look like a native android button even though it's drawn
on the screen using skia so your development speed is going to be nice and fast because again cross platform you're writing all the
code in one code base and then it just works on both ios and android and the
maintenance costs should be low but i've put this at medium for the same reason i gave
progressive web apps a rating of medium as well because it's a bespoke ui so when ios
and android completely redesign their operating systems and how they look you will have to recreate your ui as
